ontology.Main Concepts:
- Declining force of natural selection with age
- "Selection shadow" in post-reproductive life
- Accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations
- Aging as a collection of late-onset genetic disorders
ontology.__1: (("mutation accumulation"[tiab]) AND ("selection shadow"[tiab] OR "late-acting"[tiab] OR medawar[au])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: ("mutation accumulation"[tiab] OR "selection shadow"[tiab] OR "late-acting"[tiab] OR medawar[au]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- A single gene influences multiple traits (pleiotropy)
- Genes can have beneficial effects early in life and detrimental effects late in life
- Natural selection favors genes with early-life benefits
- Aging is the unselected late-life cost of early-life fitness
- Evolutionary trade-off between reproduction and longevity
ontology.__1: (("antagonistic pleiotropy"[tiab]) OR ("pleiotropic gene*"[tiab] AND "trade-off"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh] OR "Longevity"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: (pleiotrop*[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Organisms have limited resources for reproduction vs. somatic maintenance
- Prioritizing reproduction over perfect repair is evolutionarily optimal due to extrinsic mortality
- The soma (body) is "disposable" after reproduction
- Aging is the accumulation of unrepaired somatic damage
ontology.__1: (("disposable soma"[tiab]) AND ("somatic maintenance"[tiab] OR "resource allocation"[tiab] OR kirkwood[au])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: (soma[tiab] AND "somatic maintenance"[tiab] OR kirkwood[au]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging as programmed organismal death (analogous to apoptosis)
- Genetically determined and regulated biological function
- Proposed to be adaptive at the group/species level
- Frees resources and accelerates evolution
ontology.__1: (phenoptosis[tiab] OR ("programmed death"[tiab] AND ("group selection"[tiab] OR "kin selection"[tiab]))) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: (phenoptosis[tiab] OR "programmed death"[tiab] OR "group selection"[tiab] OR "kin selection"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is the result of evolutionary "experiments" in the post-reproductive soma
- Most experiments are harmful (aging), but some are beneficial for future adaptation
- The soma is "evolvable," not "disposable"
- Aging enhances a species' evolvability
ontology.__1: ("evolvable soma"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR evolution*[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: ("soma"[tiab] ) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
Aging is an evolved, adaptive process that serves as a primitive immune strategy to control the spread of infectious diseases.
It proposes that a restricted lifespan is selected for to remove older individuals from a population, as they are more likely to have accumulated a high burden of chronic pathogens.
This removal protects younger, healthier relatives from infection, thereby increasing the inclusive fitness of the lineage through kin selection.
Programmed lifespan termination is proposed as an evolutionarily stable strategy when the cost of transmitting infections to kin outweighs the benefit of a longer individual life.
ontology.__1: (("pathogen control"[tiab] OR "pathogen burden"[tiab]) AND ("lifespan"[tiab] OR "longevity"[tiab]) AND evolution*[tiab]) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- A non-adaptive byproduct of another selected characteristic
- Aging is an unavoidable consequence of complex developmental programs
- A theory of architectural constraint, not a trade-off
ontology.__1: (("spandrel"[tiab] OR "architectural constraint"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR evolution*[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: ("spandrel"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Society is structured by resource flows between age groups
- The force of selection depends on remaining fertility and net transfers
- The "transfer effect" maintains selective pressure for post-reproductive survival
ontology.__1: (("intergenerational transfer*"[tiab]) AND ("post-reproductive"[tiab] OR "inclusive fitness"[tiab] OR "grandmother hypothesis"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Longevity"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: ("intergenerational transfer*"[tiab] OR "inclusive fitness"[tiab] OR "grandmother hypothesis"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is caused by declining selection and inherent constraints on repair
- Organisms are fundamentally "unmaintainable"
- Constraints include information loss and diminishing returns on repair
ontology.__1: ("danaid theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab] OR "somatic decay"[tiab]))
ontology.__2: ("danaid"[tiab] ) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Explains long post-reproductive lifespan in human females (menopause)
- Post-menopausal women increase inclusive fitness by helping kin
- Grandmotherly assistance increases grandchildren's survival
ontology.__1: ("grandmother hypothesis"[tiab]) AND ("menopause"[tiab] OR "post-reproductive"[tiab] OR "inclusive fitness"[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are byproducts of metabolism
- ROS cause cumulative oxidative damage to macromolecules
- This damage leads to cellular dysfunction and aging
ontology.__1: (("free radical theory"[tiab] OR "oxidative stress"[tiab]) AND (ROS[tiab] OR "reactive oxygen species"[tiab] OR harman[au])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: ("free radical"[tiab] OR "oxidative stress"[tiab] OR ROS[tiab] OR "reactive oxygen species"[tiab] ) AND (theory[tiab] OR theories[tiab] OR hypothes*[tiab] OR framework*[tiab] OR paradigm*[tiab] OR "ultimate cause"[tiab] OR "proximate cause"[tiab] OR "evolution*"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Damage to somatic DNA accumulates over time
- DNA repair is imperfect
- Accumulated damage leads to mutations and genomic instability, causing aging
ontology.__1: (("somatic dna damage"[tiab] OR "somatic mutation"[tiab] OR "genomic instability"[tiab]) AND ("dna repair"[tiab] OR aging[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2: ("somatic dna damage"[tiab] OR "somatic mutation"[tiab] OR "genomic instability"[tiab] ) AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Chemical cross-links form between large molecules over time
- Glycation (reaction with sugars) forms Advanced Glycation End-products (AGEs)
- Cross-linking causes tissue stiffness and impaired function
ontology.__1: (("cross-linking theory"[tiab] OR "glycation"[tiab] OR "advanced glycation end-products"[tiab] OR AGEs[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Errors in protein synthesis machinery create a positive feedback loop
- Leads to an exponential cascade of faulty proteins
- "Error catastrophe" causes cellular death and aging
ontology.__1: ("error catastrophe theory"[tiab] OR (orgel[au] AND "protein synthesis"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is driven by a decline in proteome integrity (Loss of Proteostasis)
- Caused by increased protein damage and decreased quality control (chaperones, autophagy)
- Leads to accumulation of toxic protein aggregates
ontology.__1: (("proteostasis"[tiab] OR "protein aggregation"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Mitochondria are the primary source and target of ROS
- A "vicious cycle" of mtDNA damage, dysfunction, and increased ROS production
- Leads to cellular energy decline and senescence
ontology.__1: (("mitochondrial theory of aging"[tiab] OR "mitochondrial dysfunction"[tiab]) AND ("mtdna"[tiab] OR "bioenergetic*"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])
ontology.__2:
("mitochondrial theory of aging"[tiab] OR "mitochondrial dysfunction"[tiab] OR "mtdna"[tiab])
AND (aging[tiab] OR ageing[tiab] OR Aging[MeSH] OR Geriatrics[MeSH] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Majr] OR "Aging/physiology"[Majr])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Cell membranes become more rigid and less fluid with age
- Caused by lipid peroxidation and altered lipid composition
- Impairs function of membrane proteins, disrupting cellular homeostasis
ontology.__1: (("membrane theory of aging"[tiab] OR "membrane rigidity"[tiab] OR "membrane fluidity"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Lifelong accumulation of metabolic waste (e.g., lipofuscin) in post-mitotic cells
- Waste clogs lysosomes, impairing autophagy
- Leads to a "garbage catastrophe" and cellular dysfunction
ontology.__1: (("waste accumulation"[tiab] OR "garbage catastrophe"[tiab] OR "lipofuscin"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- The body, like a machine, wears out over time from continuous use
- Aging is the result of accumulated damage from internal and external stressors
ontology.__1: ("wear and tear theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Normal cells have a finite number of divisions (Hayflick Limit)
- Caused by progressive shortening of telomeres
- Critically short telomeres trigger irreversible growth arrest (senescence)
ontology.__1: (("replicative senescence"[tiab] OR "telomere shortening"[tiab] OR "hayflick limit"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is genetically controlled and follows a biological timetable
- Regulated by sequential activation/deactivation of "gerontogenes"
- Conserved signaling pathways (e.g., insulin/IGF-1) control the rate of aging
ontology.__1: (("programmed longevity"[tiab] OR "gerontogenes"[tiab] OR "gene regulation"[tiab]) AND ("aging"[tiab] OR "longevity"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Longevity"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is controlled by a programmed restriction in the cell's ability to translate specific codons
- Caused by changes in tRNAs or their charging enzymes
- Impairs synthesis of specific proteins, leading to dysfunction
ontology.__1: ("codon restriction theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is controlled by a biological clock in the neuroendocrine system (hypothalamus)
- Hypothalamus loses sensitivity to hormonal feedback, disrupting homeostasis
- Acts as a "pacemaker" for systemic aging
ontology.__1: (("neuroendocrine theory"[tiab] OR "hormonal theory of aging"[tiab]) AND (hypothalamus[tiab] OR pituitary[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is caused by the decline of the immune system (immunosenescence)
- Involves decline in adaptive immunity and increase in chronic inflammation (inflammaging)
- Leads to increased susceptibility to infection and age-related diseases
ontology.__1: (("immunological theory of aging"[tiab] OR "immunosenescence"[tiab] OR "inflammaging"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Immunosenescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is a purposeless continuation of developmental growth programs (quasi-program)
- Growth-promoting pathways (e.g., mTOR) become "hyperfunctional" in adulthood
- Cellular hyperfunction directly drives age-related diseases
ontology.__1: (("hyperfunction theory"[tiab] OR "quasi-program"[tiab] OR blagosklonny[au]) AND (aging[tiab] OR mtor[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is a late-life consequence of the continued action of developmental programs
- Driven by "developmental inertia" rather than a specific aging program
- Provides a mechanistic basis for antagonistic pleiotropy
ontology.__1: (("developmental theory of aging"[tiab] OR "ontogenetic drift"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Senescent cells (in permanent growth arrest) accumulate with age
- They secrete a pro-inflammatory Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP)
- SASP drives tissue dysfunction, chronic inflammation, and aging
ontology.__1: ("cellular senescence"[tiab] OR "senescence-associated secretory phenotype"[tiab] OR SASP[tiab]) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Cellular Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- The number and/or function of adult stem cells decline with age
- Caused by both intrinsic damage and extrinsic changes in the stem cell niche
- Compromises tissue regeneration and maintenance
ontology.__1: (("stem cell exhaustion"[tiab] OR "stem cell decline"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR senescence[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Stem Cells"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is caused by the progressive loss of the stable, differentiated state of cells
- Leads to "transcriptional noise" and loss of cellular identity
- Caused by deterioration of epigenetic control
ontology.__1: (("dysdifferentiation"[tiab] OR "transcriptional noise"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR "epigenetic*"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is a progressive loss of epigenetic (analog) information, not genetic (digital) information
- Caused by imperfect relocation of chromatin regulators after DNA repair
- This loss of information is potentially reversible
ontology.__1: (("information theory of aging"[tiab] OR "loss of epigenetic information"[tiab]) OR (sinclair[au] AND "epigenetic"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- The epigenome undergoes progressive, stochastic changes (drift) with age
- Involves alterations in DNA methylation and histone modifications
- Leads to transcriptional noise and is measured by epigenetic clocks
ontology.__1: (("epigenetic drift"[tiab] OR "epigenetic clock*"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR "dna methylation"[tiab])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Epigenesis, Genetic"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
* Aging can be accurately measured and predicted by analyzing predictable, age-related changes in the epigenome, most commonly DNA methylation patterns at specific CpG sites.
* These measurements are used to build algorithms, or "epigenetic clocks," that estimate an individual's biological age, which can differ from their chronological age.
* The deviation between biological (epigenetic) age and chronological age is known as "epigenetic age acceleration" and is a powerful predictor of health outcomes, disease risk, and all-cause mortality.
* Epigenetic clocks serve as critical biomarkers for understanding the aging process and evaluating the effectiveness of potential anti-aging interventions.
ontology: (("epigenetic clock"[tiab] OR "DNA methylation age"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR "biological age"[tiab] OR horvath[au])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Epigenesis, Genetic"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
* Aging is viewed as a defect in "morphostasis"â€”the active, ongoing process of maintaining a body's correct anatomical form and function.
* It is caused by the progressive loss of the complex biological information, particularly endogenous bioelectric and epigenetic signals, that guides cells to correctly build and maintain tissues and organs.
* This failure of the body's "software" or "blueprint" leads to a loss of anatomical homeostasis, causing organ malfunction and functional decline.
* The theory posits that aging is not simply the result of accumulated molecular damage, but rather a failure in the high-level, goal-directed regulatory processes that coordinate cell behavior.
ontology.__1: ((morphostasis[tiab] OR "morphostatic information"[tiab]) AND ("bioelectric*"[tiab] OR levin[au])) AND ("Aging"[Mesh] OR "Senescence"[Mesh])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Lifespan is inversely proportional to metabolic rate
- Organisms have a finite amount of "vital energy" to expend
- "Live fast, die young
ontology.__1: ("rate of living theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR "metabolic rate"[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- A modern refinement of the Rate of Living theory
- Focuses on the complex relationship between energy expenditure components and aging
ontology.__1: ("energy consumption hypothesis"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR "metabolic rate"[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is a dissipative process, an increase in entropy
- Living systems are open, self-organizing structures that dissipate energy
- Aging occurs when organisms become thermodynamically unstable
ontology.__1: (("thermodynamic theory"[tiab] OR "dissipation theory"[tiab]) AND aging[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is a stress-resistance phenotype counteracting a germ cell-inflicted death pathway
- Rooted in a germ-soma conflict over resources
- A deprivation response modulated by the reproductive phase
ontology.__1: ("deprivation-syndrome theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR "germ-soma"[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- An integrated framework of interconnected biological mechanisms driving aging
- Categorizes aging into primary, antagonistic, and integrative hallmarks
- Provides a consensus model for modern aging research
ontology.__1: ("hallmarks of aging"[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- An engineering approach to repair age-related damage
- Proposes therapies to address seven categories of damage
- Aims for "engineered negligible senescence
ontology.__1: (("sens"[tiab] OR "strategies for engineered negligible senescence"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR rejuvenation[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is an inevitable, mutual withdrawal between the individual and society
- Disengagement is natural, acceptable, and beneficial for social stability
- Allows for smooth transition of roles to younger generations
ontology.__1: ("disengagement theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR gerontology[tiab] OR elderly[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Successful aging occurs when older adults stay active and maintain social interactions
- Assumes a positive relationship between activity and life satisfaction
- Lost roles should be replaced with new activities
ontology.__1: ("activity theory"[tiab] AND ("successful aging"[tiab] OR "life satisfaction"[tiab] OR elderly[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Older adults attempt to preserve and maintain existing internal (personality, beliefs) and external (roles, relationships) structures
- Adaptation is based on past experiences and strategies
- Emphasizes consistency of lifestyle and identity
ontology.__1: ("continuity theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR "older adult*"[tiab] OR atchley[au]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- The social status of older people is inversely related to the degree of societal modernization
- Industrialization, urbanization, and mass education devalue the roles and knowledge of the elderly
ontology.__1: ("modernization theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR "social status"[tiab] OR elderly[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Society is stratified by age groups, which determines access to resources, roles, and status
- Age cohorts are influenced by their shared historical context
- Focuses on the dynamics between aging individuals and the age-graded social structure
ontology.__1: ("age stratification theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR "life course"[tiab] OR "age cohort*"[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Older people form a subculture with shared interests, problems, and a unique group consciousness
- Arises from shared experiences of aging and societal attitudes
- Fosters social integration and positive self-conception
ontology.__1: ("subculture theory"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR elderly[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Behavior is a function of the interaction between the person and their environment
- Optimal outcomes occur when personal competence matches environmental demands ("press")
- Misfit leads to negative outcomes
ontology.__1: (("person-environment fit"[tiab] OR "competence-press model"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR elderly[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Personality develops in eight sequential stages, each with a psychosocial crisis
- The final stage (late adulthood) is "Integrity vs. Despair"
- Successful resolution of crises leads to basic virtues
ontology.__1: (erikson[au] AND ("integrity vs despair"[tiab] OR "psychosocial development"[tiab])) AND (aging[tiab] OR "late adulthood"[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Elaborates on Erikson's final stages
- Defines specific psychological tasks for middle age (e.g., Valuing Wisdom vs. Physical Powers)
- Defines tasks for old age (e.g., Ego Differentiation vs. Work-Role Preoccupation)
ontology.__1: ("peck"[au] AND ("developmental tasks"[tiab] OR "ego differentiation"[tiab])) AND (aging[tiab] OR "old age"[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Development in the second half of life focuses on individuation
- Involves integrating the conscious and unconscious parts of the self
- A process of self-realization and finding meaning
ontology.__1: (jung[au] AND ("individuation"[tiab] OR "self-realization"[tiab])) AND (aging[tiab] OR "second half of life"[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- A model for successful aging and adaptation
- Individuals select specific goals, optimize resources to achieve them, and compensate for losses
- A strategy to manage the balance of gains and losses
ontology.__1: ("selective optimization with compensation"[tiab] OR "soc model"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR "successful aging"[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Focuses on the ability to perform cognitively complex tasks essential for independent living
- Involves problem-solving in real-world contexts
- Assesses Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADLs)
ontology.__1: ("everyday competence"[tiab] OR "instrumental activities of daily living"[tiab]) AND (aging[tiab] OR elderly[tiab])

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Age-related decline in fluid cognition is caused by a general decrease in the speed of processing operations
- Slower processing limits the time available for complex operations and reduces the availability of information
ontology.__1: (("cognitive slowing"[tiab] OR "processing speed"[tiab]) AND ("cognitive aging"[tiab] OR aging[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Old age can be a time of peace and freedom from bodily desires
- Allows for a greater focus on philosophy, conversation, and the pursuit of wisdom
- A positive character is key to a happy old age
ontology.__1: (plato[au] AND (aging[tiab] OR "old age"[tiab] OR wisdom[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Aging is a "natural illness," a non-pathological process of decline
- Caused by the gradual loss of "vital heat"
- Leads to both physical and mental faculties weakening
ontology.__1: (aristotle[au] AND (aging[tiab] OR "vital heat"[tiab] OR "old age"[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Authentic existence is achieved by confronting one's own finitude and mortality
- Death is the "possibility of impossibility" that defines one's being
- Awareness of death pulls one out of inauthentic everyday life
ontology.__1: (heidegger[au] AND ("being-unto-death"[tiab] OR finitude[tiab] OR mortality[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- A developmental shift in old age from a materialistic and rational view to a more cosmic and transcendent one
- Involves new understandings of self, relationships, and existential questions
- Leads to increased life satisfaction
ontology.__1: (gerotranscendence[tiab] OR (tornstam[au] AND aging[tiab]))

ontology.Main Concepts:
- Human motivation is based on a hierarchy of needs, from physiological to self-actualization
- In old age, priorities may shift back toward fundamental physiological and safety needs
- Self-transcendence can become a key goal in later life
ontology.__1: ("maslow's hierarchy"[tiab] AND (aging[tiab] OR elderly[tiab] OR gerontology[tiab] OR "palliative care"[tiab]))

Novel theory: Reproductive Cycle Theory
Novel theory: Reductive Hotspot Hypothesis
Novel theory: Executive Coupling Hypothesis

ontology.Main Concepts: Novel theory: default - executive coupling hypothesis of aging

Novel theory: Melatonin and Circadian Hypotheses

ontology.Theory Name: melatonin-based aging theories (including circadian rhythm deterioration and free radical scavenging hypothesis)
ontology.Main Concepts: Novel theory: melatonin-based aging theories (including circadian rhythm deterioration and free radical scavenging hypothesis)

ontology.Theory Name: Unified Oxidative and Genetic Programming Hypothesis
ontology.Main Concepts: Novel theory: Unified Oxidative and Genetic Programming Hypothesis
Novel theory: Adaptive Aging Interpretation

ontology.Main Concepts: Novel theory: Diminished State Space Theory of Human Aging
Novel theory: Glycation and Free Radical Theory
Novel theory: Socio-Environmental Aging Theory

ontology.Main Concepts: Novel theory: nitrogen accumulation and sleep as a reversal process
Novel theory: Network Theory of Aging

Novel theory: Quality Control Theory
